text: So no need to get rid of nanovg, there are also backends for all mainstream graphics apis

elements.text: So no need to get rid of nanovg, there are also backends for all mainstream graphics apis

text: If I were you I'd probably support some GPU style API, probably bgfx, so Mu can still take advantage of GPUs

elements.text: If I were you I'd probably support some GPU style API, probably bgfx, so Mu can still take advantage of GPUs

text: Even if it's against the core philosophy of Mu, unfortunately GPU capabilities vary wildly across vendors and generations, so abstractions are necessary

elements.text: Even if it's against the core philosophy of Mu, unfortunately GPU capabilities vary wildly across vendors and generations, so abstractions are necessary

text: And on many platforms OpenGL or OpenGL ES are the lowest level abstraction

elements.text: And on many platforms OpenGL or OpenGL ES are the lowest level abstraction

text: The philosophy of Mu is to interrogate abstractions. Definitely willing to consider this!

elements.text: The philosophy of Mu is to interrogate abstractions. Definitely willing to consider this!

text: Just found out about <https://hexler.net/products/kodelife|https://hexler.net/products/kodelife> even though I've started working on a similar project for graphics prototyping :)

elements.text: Just found out about
https://hexler.net/products/kodelife
even though I've started working on a similar project for graphics prototyping :)

text: Has anyone used it? I know there are some other web based shader toy style environments, some made by people here, like vertex shader art. My project is inspired mostly by shader toy, one thing is I want to experiment with new features like raytracing and mesh shaders in a shader toy like environment.  Kodelife is still "stuck" in DX11 level capabilities

elements.text: Has anyone used it? I know there are some other web based shader toy style environments, some made by people here, like vertex shader art. My project is inspired mostly by shader toy, one thing is I want to experiment with new features like raytracing and mesh shaders in a shader toy like environment.  Kodelife is still "stuck" in DX11 level capabilities

text: Note that in Vulkan most of those features were exposed as proprietary Nvidia extensions unlike recently and DX12 only supports them on Windows Insider builds with beta Nvidia drivers :)

elements.text: Note that in Vulkan most of those features were exposed as proprietary Nvidia extensions unlike recently and DX12 only supports them on Windows Insider builds with beta Nvidia drivers :)

text: And AMD doesn't have hardware support yet

elements.text: And AMD doesn't have hardware support yet

text: My project as shown in the video on <#C0120A3L30R|two-minute-week> was partly inspired by Kodelife, and I have experimental backends for DX12 and Vulkan. Still a a way off supporting them properly though!

text: I plan on adding support for inline raytracing with acceleration structures loaded from vox files (my main goal with this is to prototype voxel renderers) and maybe add a simple editor as well

elements.text: I plan on adding support for inline raytracing with acceleration structures loaded from vox files (my main goal with this is to prototype voxel renderers) and maybe add a simple editor as well

text: And mesh support (obj and/or gltf)

elements.text: And mesh support (obj and/or gltf)

text: Right now I'm live coding hlsl so there is no higher level language, but I will start to add a programming language to control dispatches, and ultimately I think it will end up being a general purpose high level language that defines a render graph

elements.text: Right now I'm live coding hlsl so there is no higher level language, but I will start to add a programming language to control dispatches, and ultimately I think it will end up being a general purpose high level language that defines a render graph

text: Probably graphical although I'm goin back and forth on that, I might just integrate Lua or a lisp dialect and call it a day

text:
<@UBSMEUXAA> "inline raytracing with acceleration structures loaded from vox files"

This is something I'd like to understand in more detail for my own project. What is a "vox" file (ie, what file format should I use), and how do you encode an acceleration structure in a "vox" file? Can anybody suggest a link, or an existing project that implements this, that I can study?

elements.text:
"inline raytracing with acceleration structures loaded from vox files"

This is something I'd like to understand in more detail for my own project. What is a "vox" file (ie, what file format should I use), and how do you encode an acceleration structure in a "vox" file? Can anybody suggest a link, or an existing project that implements this, that I can study?

text: Vox file is the native file format exported by Magica Voxel, a voxel editing tool

elements.text: Vox file is the native file format exported by Magica Voxel, a voxel editing tool

text: Magica Voxel has a scene editor

elements.text: Magica Voxel has a scene editor

text: So vox files support a list of instances that have transforms (3x4 matrices, representing translation and rotation), in RTX there are two acceleration structures, a top level and bottom level structure that are used to speed up ray tracing, the top level acceleration structure input looks very similar to a magica Voxel scene, instances of bottom level acceleration structures with transforms

elements.text: So vox files support a list of instances that have transforms (3x4 matrices, representing translation and rotation), in RTX there are two acceleration structures, a top level and bottom level structure that are used to speed up ray tracing, the top level acceleration structure input looks very similar to a magica Voxel scene, instances of bottom level acceleration structures with transforms

text: Any tool that uses RTX needs a way to define acceleration structures, could be an editor or import from a file (gltf can also define scenes and works for the "normal" RTX use case of triangle raytracing)

elements.text: Any tool that uses RTX needs a way to define acceleration structures, could be an editor or import from a file (gltf can also define scenes and works for the "normal" RTX use case of triangle raytracing)

text: But I could allow for scripting or pick some arbitrary restriction for a hardcoded AS as well, might be interesting to always build a regular grid structure or use a UAV and define the AS in a special compute shader

elements.text: But I could allow for scripting or pick some arbitrary restriction for a hardcoded AS as well, might be interesting to always build a regular grid structure or use a UAV and define the AS in a special compute shader
